discourse_list.title: Struggle and Progress in Democratic Governance

content.content: Andrew Hall has an interesting article, “What the History of Democracy Can Teach Us About Blockchain Governance the History of Democracy”.  There are some interesting ideas for that Maker can consider as it works to improve governance.    The Defiant – 7 Feb 22    What the History of Democracy Can Teach Us About Blockchain Governance - The... DAOs can reshape society by bringing democratic control to important economic and social activities previously governed through more hierarchical means. But as many people have pointed out, DAOs have not yet achieved their goal of true...  Est. reading time: 4 minutes       HISTORICALLY, democracies have struggled from very similar issues as Maker does today:  Low governance participation rate Delegates lack expertise and time to make informed decisions Many decisions are taken by small number of actors Government lacks mechanism to ensure these decisions are aligned with broader citizens  HISTORICALLY democracies have found the follow approaches help build better governance:  Ask voters to focus on small set of important decisions as this focuses their attention and enables them to decide key priorities Build more resilient delegation to hire good ones and fire bad ones.  Have a news ecosystems that covers and reports on both key issues and how delegates vote Elect delegates at regular intervals, helping focus voters on delegates and key issue at regular intervals Delegates appoint/fire managers to oversee operations – indirectly accountable to MKR holders Build CONSTITUTION to define roles/responsibilities of MKR holders, delegates and managers
content.GPT-summary: The post discusses the history of democracy and how it can teach us about blockchain governance. The author of the proposal explains how Maker can improve its governance by focusing on a small set of important decisions, building more resilient delegation, having a news ecosystem, electing delegates at regular intervals, appointing/firing managers, and building a constitution. The post also provides constructive criticism on the current governance participation rate, lack of expertise and time among delegates, and the need for a mechanism to ensure decisions are aligned with broader citizens.

content.content: All the points to improve governance are perfect, but the one I would highlight the most is the following:     Eumenes:  Ask voters to focus on small set of important decisions as this focuses their attention and enables them to decide key priorities   Let’s take the living example of the cypherpunks, they managed to do what cryptocurrencies are today, with perseverance and dedication, but they participated in key and important points, the excess of information for the delegates is extremely overwhelming, therefore we need to lower this excess of information and voting summaries are important too.     Eumenes:  Build CONSTITUTION to define roles/responsibilities of MKR holders, delegates and managers   This would practically be putting the endgame plan into action, so that would also be perfect.

content.content: It is worth noting Maker is a plutocracy, not a democracy. There are only a handful of Maker holders who need to come to consensus on decisions.  And unlike a democracy, it’s easy for them to sell their stake and leave. It’s a very different dynamic, because delegates typically represent one or two people or organizations. Not a broad a group.

content.content: These historical innovations in governance sound very solid and potentially helpful to Maker.  Lets learn from wherever we can; history has many good lessons in governance. Maker needs a Constitution that defines key stakeholders, principles/vision and core governance roles/responsibilities and process. Currently, there are no rights/protections or representation for DAI holders.  This is a huge oversight.  Maker has over 5 billion of non-crypto loan DAI holders:  who represents and protects their interests?  Without a growing base of DAI holders, Maker will not succeed.

content.content: A current problem of our times, but democracies are already old. I think that one of the vectors of low participation is the lack of simple, easy to assimilate and summarized information that currently exists about Maker and its processes. In addition, Ethereum’s gas always motivates them not to participate, the best thing would be delegates, but superdelegates that over time are only incentivized by increasing the size of the budget they can get, does not seem to be the solution either. It would be better to have delegates with short participation times, without direct opportunity to participate again, possibly alternating. It would be from my point of view the best, shorter to apply and a little less susceptible to failures.
